729589f-a.text:
St. Marks Place, east side, between Hamilton Avenue and Nicholas Street, showing the sumptuous Castleton Hotel. It was built in 1889 on the site of the old St. Marks Hotel and the 'Marble House" of Gilbert L. Thompson, son-in-law of Governor Tompkins. The Hotel was burned November 12, 1907.
About 1905
By Bulford Simonson
From Staten Island Museum Collection through P. L. Sperr
729589f-a.folder: St. Marks Place & Hamilton Avenue, Staten Island, NY
729589f-a.original_title: Richmond: St. Marks Place - Hamilton Avenue

729590f-a.text:
St. Marks Place, north from Hamilton Avenue to Nicholas Street, showing Curtis High School (left) and Castleton Park, exclusive residential development, occupying the former site of the famous Castleton Hotel. The white 7-story building is the Castleton apartments,. at the S.E. corner of Nicholas Street. Beyond that (at the N.E. corner) is the Wisteria Apartments.
May 2, 1928
P. L. Sperr
729590f-a.folder: St. Marks Place & Hamilton Avenue, Staten Island, NY
729590f-a.original_title: Richmond: St. Marks Place - Hamilton Avenue

728905f-b.text:
Hamilton Avenue, at its western intersection with St. Marks Place, showing Curtis High School. The two wings were not part of the original school building, but were added on years later.
Views 1,21 May 2, 1928
View 3: June 22, 1937
P. L. Sperr
728905f-b.folder: Hamilton Avenue & St. Marks Place, Staten Island, NY
728905f-b.original_title: Richmond: Hamilton Avenue - St. Marks Place
